notes: On 31 March 2021, unidentified gunmen abducted two Chinese workers at Oba (Obafemi-Owode LGA, Ogun). Gunmen demanded ransom. Kidnapped victims were later released. Unclear whether ransom was paid.

On 20 March 2021, a group of people marched in Ingende (Ingende, Equateur) to protest against Chinese business owners who cut timber in their territory, demanding business compliance to logging protocols. [size=no report]

On 6 March 2021, a group of people who work at COMMUS, a Chinese-owned mining company, marched in Kolwezi (Kolwezi, Lualaba) to protest against the company's lack of worker benefits and to demand higher wages, medical insurance and representation in the absence of a syndicate organization. [size=no report]
On 2 March 2021, unidentified gunmen abducted a Chinese construction supervisor at Igbemo-Ekiti (Irepodun/Ifelodun LGA, Ekiti). Reason for abduction unknown.

Around 7 February 2021, members of the Mayi Mayi militia raided a hotel in the TP 32 suburb of Mambasa's trading center (Mambasa, Ituri), which allegedly serves as the headquarters of a Chinese mining company. According to reports, the militiamen killed one or two civilians and wounded one or two others. Subsequent to this event, members of the Congolese military forces, the FARDC, detained 6 Mayi Mayi militia men.

On 1 February 2021, Fulani pastoralists clashed with a police operative attached to three Chinese workers at Ifewara (Atakumosa East LGA, Osune), and abducted the workers. Militiamen demanded ransom. Victims were later released. Unclear whether ransom was paid. One reported fatality.
On 1 February 2021, workers of the Chinese mining company Lualaba Cooper Smelter marched in Kolwezi (Kolwezi, Lualaba) to demand better working conditions and wages. [size=no report]

On 28 January 2021, a group of residents barricaded the main road near a mining site (Gecamines Kapata) 15 km from Kolwezi town (Kolwezi, Lualaba). They showed their outrage for the death of a Congolese worker the previous day and accused Chinese workers of being the perpetrators (unconfirmed). The police intervened and dispersed the crowd. [size=no report]

Around 21 December 2020 (as reported), the decapitated body of a chief who was abducted along with four other people by Al Shabaab militants (previously coded) on 18 January was found along the Chinese cutline between Koton and Khorof Harar town (Wajir East, Wajir).

Around 16 December 2020 (as reported), violence erupted between Hausa miners and Chinese expatriates at Idoko village (Obokun LGA, Osun) over access to a mining site. Two reported fatalities. [size=no report]
On 14 December 2020, unidentified gunmen abducted a Chinese national at Gindin Dorowa (Wukari LGA, Taraba) but were repelled by Nigerian police operatives. One reported fatality.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 2 December 2020, unidentified militiamen ambushed and killed 1 Chinese civilian with machetes in Basimbi village, near Kitumba (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). The victim was a worker of the Chinese company Bluent Mineral Mining, which operates in the area.

actor1: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
notes: On 30 November 2020, Mayi-Mayi rebel combatants (unidentified group) clashed with the FARDC in an unspecified goldmine in Mambasa territory (Mambasa, Ituri), following an incursion by these rebels. 2 rebels were killed and 1 civilian was shot dead by a stray bullet. The Mayi-Mayi, who managed to loot this goldmine run by Chinese nationals, abducted 7 civilians (5 of them women), and forced them to carry the loot.

On 27 November 2020, unidentified gunmen clashed with a police operative attached to a Chinese Engineer along the new Ado-Iyin Road in Ado-Ekiti (Ado Ekiti LGA, Ekiti), and abducted the Engineer. One reported fatality and one injury. Victim was later released. Unclear whether ransom was paid.
On 24 October 2020, a group of construction workers of a Chinese company demonstrated in Tshikapa (Kamonia, Kasai) to demand their unpaid salaries for the last 4 months. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, more than 4,000 fish maw traders in Nyanza region protested in Homa Bay town (Homa Bay, Homa Bay), against the setting up of two Chinese firms for the commodity in Homa Bay and Mbita towns. The protestors claimed that the companies would bring unfair competition and render them jobless. [size=more than 4,000]

On 9 October 2020, the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) detained six foreign fishing boats and arrested 54 Chinese nationals on the Coast of Johor. The vessels allegedly entered the Malaysian part of the South China Sea without permission.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 11 August 2020, 7 unidentified armed men clashed with private security guards at a mining site in Kakula (Kolwezi, Lualaba) following an incursion by these 7 attackers. 1 Chinese national of the company Zijin Mining Group Co, which runs the mine, was killed in the attack and 1 Congolese national was also shot and injured.
On 22 July 2020, unidentified gunmen clashed with police officers and abducted 4 Chinese workers in Oban (Akamkpa LGA, Cross River). 1 police officer who guarded the company was killed.
On 3 June 2020, unidentified gunmen abducted 2 Chinese miners from a mining site in Ihietutu in Ishiagu (Ivo LGA, Ebonyi)

On 2 May 2020, Mayi-Mayi militiamen (Simba) under the leadership of Luc Yabili carried out an incursion and clashed with FARDC soldiers for more than 2 hours in the mining site of Muchacha, near Badengaido (Mambasa, Ituri). The FARDC managed to force the rebels out but 3 soldiers were killed and 1 injured. This site is a gold mining site run by a Chinese company.

On 25 April 2020, a local youth gang ambushed a Chinese mining convoy accompanied by police officers on their way from a mining site to Abakaliki (Eboyni LGA, Ebonyi). 1 Police officer was stabbed to death and his rifle stolen.
On 21 April 2020, over 100 followers of a clergyman demonstrated at the Chinese embassy in Lagos (Lagos Island LGA, Lagos) over the ill-treatment of Nigerians in China. [size=over 100]

actor1: CODECO: Cooperative for Development of Congo
notes: Between 4 and 5 April 2020, an armed clash ensued between CODECO militiamen and FARDC forces in a mining area in Sumbabho, near Mwanga (Ituri). The clash resulted in three Chinese civilians and a FARDC official dead. It was reported the Chinese were mining gold and the Congolese military was committed to protect them. The perpetrators stole gold before escaping.

On 19 March 2020, Mimbulu market sellers set tires and barricades on fire in demonstration in the neighbourhood of Upemba, in Lubumbashi (Haut-Katanga), against the municipality's decision to sell part of the market. Rioters attacked a Chinese passer-by, who was saved by police officers before the latter started shooting in the air to disperse rioters. [size=no report]

On Jan 1, 2020, more than 300 Muslim students held a protest in Kuala Lumpur to simultaneously rally public support for the jawi script and to demand the government ban the Chinese group, Dong Zong, for opposing plans to teach the jawi script. The protest was prohibited by the police under the Peaceful Assembly Act, but the students proceeded to protest. The police summoned four students regarding the protest. [size=more than 300]
On 26 November 2019, unidentified gunmen attacked a mining site in Itagunmodi, killed a police officer on duty and abducted three Chinese workers. One worker sustained gunshot wounds.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 21 November 2019, unidentified persons abducted 3 Chinese workers of a mine company in Kitumba, Matebo, groupement Bingilibazala, chefferie de Wamuzimu, Mwenga. 2 FARDC soldiers and another civilian were injured.

On 28 October 2019, civil society activists reportedly held a march from Kitutu to Kitumba in Sud-Kivu, Mwenga territory, in Beni city of Nord-Kivu (coded to Kitutu), to protest against the illicit exploitation of local minerals by Chinese companies in the area. [size=no report]

On Oct 17, 2019, more than a hundred protesters of Chinese nationality held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, regarding fraud by a Malaysian investment company. The protesters urged the Chinese embassy to look into their plight. [size=more than 100]
On Sept 29, 2019, around 70 people, mostly young ethnic Chinese, held a small rally in Kuala Lumpur in support of the ongoing protests in Hong Kong. [size=around 70]

On July 5, 2019, around 30 protesters from Muslim NGOs coalition, including ABIM: Muslim Youth Movement of Malaysia and MAPIM: Malaysian Consultative Council Of Islamic Organisations, held a 30 minute peaceful protest outside China Embassy in Kuala Lumpur. They urged the Chinese government to cease its alleged oppression of the Uighurs in Xinjiang. [size=30]

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 17 June, near Blukwa, an unidentified armed group attacked a convoy of Chinese mine workers and FARDC soldiers, who were accompanying the party. In the ensued firefight 1 FARDC soldier and 1 Chinese national were killed. On 20 June, a provincial deputy has been arrested, together with other 14 people, and accused of organizing the attack.

On 16 June 2019, outside the Kuala Lumpur Selangor Chinese Assembly Hall in Kuala Lumpur, a group of about 50 Malaysians dressed in black gathered in solidarity with Hong Kong demonstrators against the Hong Kong government's proposed extradition law with mainland China. More than 60 police personnel barred the demonstrators from marching towards the city center causing the group to stage a silent protest by siting on the road. Two women from China also participating in the demonstration were detained under immigration law after not being able to produce identification documents. [size=50]
23 April: Kibwezi residents held demonstration against Chinese company exhuming body parts from grave yard for road construction. [Size=No report]

On 26 March 2019, some 30 MCA Youth members and some members from the youth wings of UMNO, MIC and PAS staged a demonstration at the controversial fallen Japanese soldiers' monument in Alor Setar city, Kota Setar, Kedah. They are calling for the monument to be removed and for respect for the Chinese community in the country. [size=30]

On 26 March 2019, Penang MCA Youth handed over a memorandum to the Penang Japanese Consulate in George Town, Northeast Penang Island, Penang. They are calling for the monument to be removed and for respect for the Chinese community in the country. [size=no report]

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 17 March 2019, an unidentified armed group of approximately 40 militia members attacked the Kimya gold mine, at the Muchacha mining site and near Epulu village (Mambasa, Ituri). The assailants killed two Chinese workers and one Congolese. They also looted 50,000 USD and 50 grams of gold.
02 January. Mayi Mayi Fimbo na Fimbo Bitonto ambushed a company convoy near Mulange village. One person was killed and others were injured, including a Chinese employee of the company.

On 14 December 2018, at Seputeh's MP Teresa Kok's office in Kuchai Lama in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL), the Malaysian Chinese Association Youth chief and 10 group members brought baskets of palm oil fruit bunches to protest Kok's failure to address the issues of palm oil smallholders.

On 25 November 2018, around a hundred Tamil parents held a peaceful protest in front of the Serendah Chinese Primary School in Serendah mukim (Serendah, Selangor). They demanded the prime minister open a Tamil school in Serendah as promised during the election campaign. [size=around 100]

On or before October 25th, residents from the Katimokor area of Chepchoina (Trans Nzoia) protested against the mining operations of a Chinese firm, and the role of local authorities in granting the company permission to mine the area. The source indicates that the company is embroiled in a pre-existing land dispute in the area.

On 22 Sept 2018, local labourers of a Chinese company contracted to lay tarmac on Suguta-Maralal road staged a protest in front of Sino Hydro's office in Maralal town denouncing poor working conditions and non-payment of overtime.

Arrests: During the week leading up to 8th September, Kenyan police reportedly arrested 163 Pakistani nationals in the city of Mombasa, as part of a nation-wide crackdown on illegal immigration. On September 5th, police also raided the offices of the China Global Television Network in Nairobi, arresting 13 Chinese civilians (including journalists).

On 21 July 2018, some 400 students staged a demonstration in the city center in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) against the government's possible move to recognize the Unified Examination Certificate in Chinese independent schools.

On 11 July 2018, four Chinese security guards at the Malaysia-China Kuantan Industrial Park (MCKIP) were injured after being attacked by a mob of more than 50 people in Gebeng town (Kuantan, Pahang) which was incited by a false allegation that a local lorry driver was beaten to death in the area on July 10.
06 June. Environmental groups protest in Nairobi over the construction of a Chinese power plant in Lamu.
Protests against a group of Chinese construction workers in Ibadan. The protesters accused the construction workers of damaging utility and the management of insensitivity to the people's plight.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 15 February 2018, an unidentified armed group killed a civilian in the commune of Kadutu, in Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), over an exchange of money. The victim was murdered with a Chinese grenade. An hour later around 20h, another armed group tried to pillage some boutiques in the Nguba side of the Ibanda commune. 2 other civilians died while trying to save themselves during this attack.
A Chinese miner is attacked and killed and another injured by gunmen in Alogani. The motive for the attack ins not known.
Residents protest an alleged land takeover by a Chinese company.
Two Chinese nationals are kidnapped in Odeda LGA. The pair was rescued in the following week.
Unidentified gunmen kidnap two Chinese workers in Agada (Agwada).
Unidentified gunmen kidnap two Chinese workers in Agada (Agwada). The two were later rescued.

Youths, wielding weapons, attacked a group of Chinese workers contracted to build a railway in Duka Moja, Narok County. The attack is related to a protest the previous day in which the group had demanded locals be hired by labourers. Injuries reported.
Youths protest after Chinese nationals had been contracted to build a railway rather than locals.
50 visa-seekers staged a sit-in in front of the Chinese embassy in Kinshasa against the establishment of a separate agency to handle visa application, due to expected fee increases.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: A Chinese businessman involved in purchasing malachite was found dead in his private residence. A security source says he was 'killed with sharp objects' implying that it was likely a murder (no report of suicide).
Nigerians working for a Chinese company protested their employment termination.
Thousands of local fabric dyers staged a peaceful demonstration against the importation of Chinese textile and engagement of the expatriates in retail sale of fabrics in Kano Market.
Employees of a Chinese construction company protest compensation they believe unfair.
Workers of a Chinese construction firm protest employment termination.

Following 5 murders over 5 days, residents rioted, ransacking and burning the town hall, and looting some Chinese owned shops. Police and military forces clashed with the rioters before restoring order.

A group of Kenyan youths protest a Chinese Restaurants policy of refusing entry to local people during the nigh time hours. The protest turned violent, however, when the group began looting the restaurant. No injury reported.
Unidentified gunmen kidnap three Chinese workers in Lokoja. It was not immediately clear if the motive was ransom-taking. One police officer was killed when the gunmen launched their attack.
At least 3 Chinese nationals were seriously injured and over 50-53 Chinese owned stores were looted by rioters during the protests against the electoral law.

Over 100 youths working for a Chinese company, Linda Manufacturing Company at Agege protested to Lagos State House of Assembly over the death of their colleague. The protesting workers alleged he was denied medical treatment after he complained of stomach pain.
Unidentified gunmen kill a Chinese national contractor and wound two others in a small border village situated along Plateau State.

Al Shabaab attacks pedestrians in a shopping centre during mid-day, arriving in three separate groups using three different entrances. 68 dead, including private security staff, 150  injured over four days, hostages taken. Witnesses claim the attack was highly organised, with the attackers having pre-positioned weapons throughout the building, as well as obtaining access to service elevators. Following the attack al Shabaab claimed responsibility. There were claims the group specifically targeted non-Muslims. Foreigners were among those confirmed dead, including British, American, French, Canadians, Indians, a Ghanaian, a South African and a Chinese. The ordeal occurred over a four day period. Al Shabaab stated the reason for the attacks was the Kenyan military presence in Somalia.

Seven members of a members of a kidnapping syndicate, which included a Chinese national, are shot and killed by police during an exchange of gunfire. The group is believed to be responsible for the kidnap of a local council development area in the state, Kehinde Bamigbetan and a judge with the High Court. The exact location of the shootout is not clear.
A Chinese teacher based at Kamina barracks got angry at a FARDC soldier for killing his pet and killed him.
Employees of a Chinese-owned nylon bag manufacturing company gather on Awosika Avenue in Ikeja to protest a co-workers death and demand safer working conditions.
Workers at geothermal plan stage protest over working conditions as part of ongoing strike; rioters attack Chinese company officer
Tea farmers stage demonstration against Chinese water company that they claim is ruining their roads
Gunmen shot and killed two Chinese construction workers in rural Borno state, motive unknown.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
notes: A Chinese construction worker and three Nigerian civilians are shot and killed by suspected Boko Haram.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram gunmen attack a small town market with firearms, killing three Chinese construction workers an a Nigeria aid.
Traders protest on streets of Nairobi over Chinese businesses which are undercutting their own business
Vigilante mob attack Chinese citizens they suspected of selling counterfeit mobile phones

Traders begin a protest march against some Chinese business men who they accused of undermining and killing their businesses. Speaking during the protest, the national Chairman of the association, Mr. Azubike Nwachukwu , said Nigerian dealers have been operating at a loss since the Chinese business men started retail selling of the leather products at a very cheap price.
Residents of Membley Estate in Kiambu county yesterday blocked the Ruiru-Kiambu bypass, protesting at Chinese contractors constructing the Thika Superhighway, thereby flooding their homes.
A mob associated with the Vuyamu church ransacked properties belonging to Chinese and Indian residents in an apparent act of xenophobic violence.
